job_title: Center Manager in Great Lakes, IL
pros: Pay Paid Time Off (You'll never get to use it though) Volunteers can be friendly Company Store has decent items 401K Match is competitive
cons: Leadership is hired from corporate america, and often are paid far higher than anyone else in the company. HR is solely to protect upper leadership and in no way is there to support the team. The company is entirely focused on fundraising and elite donor relations. Volunteers and Service Members are at the bottom of the list. It is no wonder that other organizations have started to pop up in the gaps left by USO's poor support of the military. You will never get to use PTO, and will lose any accrued PTO when you leave the company, regardless of the circumstances.

pros: -Love supporting military -Great people to work with
cons: -non-profit dollars always a challenge -Challenges of having a US based HQ.

job_title: Director Development in New York, NY
pros: Wonderful mission. Everyone who works here is passionate about supporting the military and their families.
cons: Not the most innovative in their fundraising techniques.

review_title: Low pay for workers high pay for executives
job_title: Center Operations and Program Manager in Jacksonville, FL
pros: The benefits are good and fairly priced.
cons: There are a lot of cons for working at this job.

pros: Great support to military around the world
cons: If you don't drink the kool aide you won't progress

review_title: I love the mission the USO supports
pros: Generous PTO for all employees.
cons: They ask you to stay in your position for a year before promoting, while living overseas that can be a difficult task, so it doesn't promote growth while you're stationed overseas.

pros: Great mission and colleagues. Decent health benefits and excellent retirement plan, if you last that long.
cons: Incompetent leadership and toxic culture. Development leadership is clueless and just wants to grind away at staff to make issues disappear. No clear direction and strategies change twice a year or more often. Growth is discouraged and massive gatekeeping of information,

review_title: As a spouse of an active duty US Army
pros: Was able to serve and be part of the military family community
cons: Nothing I could ask for more since they helped me also to expand my social life and experience service for the military families

job_title: Field Programs Specialist in Arlington, VA
pros: Love that you get to interact and do programs with not only Service Members but also Military Spouses, Military Children, and the whole Family. Lots of new and exciting Programs and Events are at your fingertips, you just have to have the creative mindset, ideas, and enthusiasm to make it all happen.
cons: Because USO us a non profit organization, the pay is not the greatest but because the job is so rewarding and fun, the pay is tolerable.

pros: Working with super people - and providing support to our service members.
cons: The hours are pretty tough - but you can control them.

pros: Mission is wonderful, center staff and volunteers are passionate
cons: Leadership team is weak, doesn't really leave, doesn't value staff or what they bring to the job. Very toxic culture with rampant favoritism and cliques. The top leaders make HUGE salaries but do not take real leadership - no vision, no strategy. Cutting back programs that have impact and use way too much money on "leadership". Lots of turnover at HQ level among staff that actually work because of the failure of leadership to be fair, honest or accountable. Stayed 12+ years hoping it would get better but the bullying finally forced me to leave. I will support troops another way!

pros: Flexible, Feel good to work there
cons: Overworked when on shift, often placed in areas where there is high traffic

pros: This is the most rewarding, fulfilling, purpose-filled job I have ever had. My heart is genuinely full when I'm doing my job. I see the impact our organization makes on a daily basis and it really is meaningful work. I love to see the service members happy and it makes me feel really good when I know we're doing something great for them. Our mission is one that I stand by strongly and believe there are many others within our organization who feel the same way.
cons: The workplace culture is not always great. We see subpar managers get pushed into higher positions and called "leaders" or moved around to avoid conflict, but nothing really changes. Work-Life balance is not always the best and sometimes I feel like superiors know that they can get away with asking us to do more for the same pay because we care deeply about the service members and the USO mission.

review_title: Great company for supporting our troops!
pros: Non-center staff can potentially work from home or work hybrid. Health, Dental, Vision, Life insurance & 401k available. Technology equipment is new. Directly or indirectly support US Service Members.
cons: Pay is not competitive. High stress environment. Internal promotions are unlikely to happen. Not all management adhere to company values. High turn over rates for center staff.

pros: Get to spend time with Service Members. Get to help them with a lot of different areas of needs around the world.
cons: Not much room for growth if you aren't a retired CSM or Officer.

job_title: Field Programs Specialist in Schofield Barracks, HI
pros: Enjoyable and rewarding place to work because of the service members and volunteers.
cons: Poor management/leadership, no growth/development, no work/life balance, management isn’t held accountable. It appears that the leadership team and HR lets the managers get away with a lot.

pros: Great people and place to work
cons: The pay could be higher

pros: Travel, Helping Others, Danger Pay
cons: Work 6 days a week and lack of privacy

pros: Good sense of purpose and rewarding work
cons: Overworked and micromanaged, Employee appreciation is almost non existent

job_title: Service Center Operation Supervisor in San Antonio, TX
pros: Soldiers Families Salary is decent
cons: Not enough volunteers Little budget Leaders don’t care Overworked and exhausted from multiple occasions of working 7+ days straight

pros: Strong mission driven company; providing unwavering support to military members and families; global impact and opportunities; great focus on volunteer and partner engagement, ability to work with people across the world; implementing diversity and inclusion initiatives
cons: internal transparency and communication from top executive leaders, laying off employees without any notice, prioritizing positions that raise money over positions that directly deliver the mission

pros: Great Team! Love the environment and culture!
cons: Understanding the mission importance and support is hard to illuminate to the public.

pros: Amazing mission with passionate employees. You actually see the difference you're making if you work in the field.
cons: Toxic culture. Having a life outside of work is looked down upon. Long hours, every employee I've worked with is burnt out and underpaid. No room for growth, promotion, or salary increase. Low paying salaries compared to other non-profits. Toxic management, HR does nothing about it. Management is petty and territorial.

job_title: Center Operations Manager in Schofield, HI
pros:
*Supports service members and their families by providing services, programs, and events.
*Allowed creative freedom for innovative ideas
*Cross-trained among many different categories such as program planning and management, marketing, social media, volunteer management, accounting, and administrative work
*Worked with wonderful individuals who donated their time to support service members and their families.
cons:
*Work and life balance is almost non-existent 
*Salary position requires up to 88 hours per week
*Salary does not align with the long list of responsibilities as well as the area
*Lack of organization, focus, and professionalism
*Information, marketing, programs, and events pushed from Corporate are typically last minute causing most staff members to scramble to successfully execute marketing and programs
*Passive-aggressive management that causes staff members to feel unwelcomed and uncomfortable
*Recognition is uncommon for staff members
*Lack of proper training for new staff members
*Learning curve is immense due to the number of responsibilities 
*Higher management does not retain fundamental information on policies and procedures, therefore, cannot train subordinates, complete tasks, and follow these policies and procedures
*High expectations regarding volunteers, program numbers, facility foot traffic with a small budget
*Difficult to move up within the organization

pros: Great place to work! You work with your team to bring the best experience to military and their families.
cons: A lot of attention to tiny tiny detail.

pros: You get to make a difference and bring joy to the lives of service members and their families.
cons: There is a lot of attention to detail, but when you get that down, it's a piece of cake.

pros: Love mission! All about the service members!
cons: Pay more. People leave because of the salaries vs high level of work/expectations.

pros: Great working wity volunteers and clients Pay was decent
cons: Management is absent and leadership unwilling to listen Staff is never at the center

pros: Fast paced work environment where no day is the same. There are plenty of opportunities to bring your own creative ideas to life. This specific role plays a heavy part in the well being of the community, and truly shows the importance of the organization. The work will always be rewarding, meaningful and impactful.
cons: Starting salary is less than desirable for the amount of work required, but yearly bonuses will make it manageable after a few years. Work culture is demanding and stressful, especially if you care about the work you do. The cultural differences working in this center can be frustrating.

pros: The volunteers The service members and their families
cons: Leadership is highly nepotistic on the local level and would benefit greatly from some training on staff development.

pros: Good salary and PTO policy. It looked like career progression was possible, but then it depended on who liked you.
cons: If you're comfortable with the possibility of being laid off every ~3 years, no guarantee that you'll move up to the next position, and fairly conservative leadership, then this Development and Marketing Team could be a good fit. They do a re-org every ~3 years in this department. The team member demographic doesn't properly reflect our Military.

pros: Although the organization is currently going through a lot of growing pains, the staff are very passionate about the mission and the people it serves. They support hiring military spouses who tend to move frequently, and work with staff who want to grow within the organization, but in different departments.
cons: There is currently a lot of turn over in staff, so some historical knowledge is lost along the way.

pros: Many opportunities for experience in the field. Working with the military community. Doing work that matters (in the field). Plenty of diversity. Opportunities to see the world & experience & support the military first-hand. Plenty of creative & operational freedom in field locations.
cons: Low compensation. MANY hours of OT if you do field work because you are stretched thin. No car allowance & you will put a LOT of miles & wear & tear on your own vehicle. Many locations have weak leadership. Turf wars & politics rule HQ. Operations out of HQ is run by fear/intimidation. Many in the field & in HQ office are afraid to speak up out of legitimate, evidence-backed fear of retribution. USO (unnecessarily) spins stories for donations & then wastes millions due to high-profile, expensive pandering for media and poor planning that causes rework or work that never sees the light of day. They pay for consultants & ignore them. They hire intelligent employees & tell them to do their work as told without challenging anything. Change communications are awful. 250 locations reinvent many wheels. Does the USO do a lot of good? Absolutely. But most of it happens in the field despite HQ. Many of the really good employees in the organization leave because of poor leadership, limited career paths & lack of genuine appreciation for their work. Those who know better also know NOT to confide in HR. There is no confidentiality. Everything gets back to leadership & will come back to bite them. Much of the same leadership has been in place for far too long, just churning through employees year after year. It's a dysfunctional workplace culture fueled by mistrust. HQ creates its own ego-driven obstacles to having more impact. After seeing the amount of $ wasted, I don't recommend donating to the USO, or at least not through HQ. Give directly to the local USO chapter. They work their tails off for every donation they get, and they don't squander $. The military definitely needs & deserves the support, but USO HQ needs an overhaul.

pros: Direct, hands-on impact with service members and military communities. High level of autonomy.
cons: Inconsistent guidance from high-level leadership on organizational priorities.

pros: Supporting the military community. And if you’re lucky. You have great immediate coworkers
cons: The management is god awful. Do NOT trust HR. If you’re a soon to be mother or parent this isn’t the place for you. So many things were reported to HR about management and they did not care in the slightest. The person is STILL working there and even got promotions 🤮. I love the organization. But man does management need to do better

pros: Work with service members daily.
cons: The salary was not as attractive.

pros: Excellent on-boarding process and procedures
cons: None at this time identified.

job_title: Center Operations Supervisor in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Friendly - team-oriented staff, incredible place to work. HR is a bit of a struggle but all issues are handled effectively in-house. Excellent benefits, and incredible PTO
cons: Difficult to work with so many different personalities. Volunteers can be incredibly self-entitled, forgetting the importance and meaning of the mission.

pros: You can make a difference for our nations heroes.
cons: I am a former volunteer. The atmosphere is toxic, and the leader encourages people to tattle on each other. There is no appreciation, and the leadership actively pushes away other organizations who want to work with them. There are never enough supplies

pros: Great place to work...you stay busy.
cons: Long hours at work but it pays off.

pros: The most rewarding job! Best place to meet new people and do good for the community.

job_title: Development Associate in Long Beach, CA
pros: Offered an AMAZING retirement plan matching contribution.
cons: Over worked as staff was limited

pros: Benefits and the mission are the only good thing
cons: Very toxic environment. Especially Finance and Development. Some of the people/managers have been there for a very long time (10+ yrs) and they treat people bad just because they think they can. They are arrogant and passive aggressive and should not be in the manager role. HR is useless and does not address these kinds of concerns and protects the toxic ones, and the toxicity thrives. Which is a shame, because the mission of helping military families is a good one and the work benefits are really great.

pros: Great place to volunteer, people are great!!
cons: I’ll get back to you.

review_title: Great co workers and local leadership.

review_title: Fun but hard to Support Yourself with the Salary
pros: So much fun interacting with patrons, coming up with programs and serving the community. It is a great place to make connections.
cons: The expectation is that the recruitment of volunteers is enough to make up for the amount of demand, which isn't true or enough. So much burn-out from everyone. There is not much professional growth opportunity. It is hard to support yourself with the pay.

pros: Easy going, helping service members, former service members and their families during an unfamiliar time of transition from the military.
cons: I didn't experience any needs improvement, it just wasn't the right fit for me.

review_title: Honored to be part of the USO family.
pros: The USO has a mission that I am proud to help carry out. They do a great of communicating the mission and the importance of the mission. The USO has locations all over the world which as been a plus to me as a military spouse. They offer great benefits to include paid time off and education assistance.
cons: Working for a non profit organization is a wonderful thing. Money should not be your motivator. The joy of helping carry out the mission and doing work that gives back has to be something that you love and enjoy.

job_title: Senior Operations Manager in Manhattan, KS
pros: Culture, People, Work-Life Balance, FUN
cons: Variety of hours, including nights/weekends due to nature of the job

pros:
Collaboration
Independent 
Reliable 
Mission Focused
Family Friendly
cons: Not enough time doing activities together as a team

pros: Great company to work for, opportunity for growth and fast paced work environment
cons: Additional training is needed during onboarding

pros:
Great PTO
Healthcare
 Mission
 Great Location to work
Telework Policy
cons:
I believe the organization as a whole is a good place to work, but stay clear of the development department. Senior leadership is terrible. They love to give pre written speeches on team building and team bonding, but never actually try to get to know there staff. When you are smart and know your job instead of using your strength to better the department they look at you as a threat and try to push you by if you call them out on their poor decisions. No-one is promoted for doing good work.. you are promoted if you are best friends with the CDO and VP's. They do lay offs every year and half and call it " redirecting resources". The departments that get hit the hardest are Programs, Operations, sometimes development. 

The HR department is a pointless department. Staff members are scared to voice their concerns to HR because the HR department always backs the managers (VP's/ Directors) without doing proper investigation to get the full story. So your complaint gets back to your manager and in return they find ways to push you out. They do this by micro-managing you and literally reporting to HR all your mistakes even if its something simple as emailing a team member back a day late... (literally happened to many colleagues of mine) They will continue to do this process until you either quit or they have enough "mistakes" to fire you. 

The work they do is amazing work and if you really want to join this organization go to the Finance, Operations, or Program department, but STAY CLEAR OF DEVELOPMENT!! Its the most toxic work environment I have ever worked in and no-one is valued for the many hours they work each week, oo except for the best buddies of the VP's and CDO's.

Senior Leadership, Toxic Workplace, Incompetent Managers, HR Department, Lack of Diversity

pros: Great organization to work for, with opportunity for advancement.

pros: The mission is one that makes your job fulfilling.
cons: Favoritism was very apparent in the region I worked in. If you had a good team, you could thrive. If work was wearing on us(overworked) we were reminded that we do it “for the mission” when in actuality we were stretched too thin.

review_title: One of the best places to work
pros: Meaningful mission, great culture, excellent benefits
cons: No cons working for the uso

pros: The mission is noble and the staff and volunteers that are not management do a great job delivering goodness to the troops.  The staff and volunteers truly have their hearts in the job and want to give everything they can to the troops.
cons: The executives and management are the worst ever. The senior staff needs a complete overhaul starting with Development and HR since they have the worst management in the company.  The staff works as hard as they can with the managers tying their hands behind their backs.  The Development team was completely dysfunctional the entire time I worked there and no one at the top was interested in resolving the problems that was obvious to all.  Those of us in other departments hated working with HR because of its ineffectiveness and incompetence.  The core values are only on paper and not practiced by management.

job_title: Manager, Programs Analysis in Arlington, VA
pros: everyone at the USO is driven by the mission and the desire to help people. they are truly a wonderful team and it is a great place to work.
cons: as with any non-profit the compensation is not always desirable and the room for growth within ones career path is not always clear.

pros: Passion, giving back, support of military community, support from management
cons: limited growth potential, limited funding available

pros: Great experiences helping service members
cons: If you don't like working major holidays, then this organization might not be a good fit. It's important though for service members.

review_title: Great Organization with a Phenomenal Mission.
pros: Great organization with very talent people and strong mission in serving the military community.
cons: Career progression within the organization can be challenging.

review_title: Can't Hold the Values They Claim to Uphold and Service...to Support Those Who Serve & Their Families....SMH
pros: There are many other NPOs  better equipped to help out our military where the USO so gravely fails, and can do so with much, much more support and services to address the true needs of our military (and families, veterans, and retirees).  And they can do this while respecting the funds donated to make it all possible, and legal.
cons:
A common theme heard in the office was, "It's for the troops, we won't have to lift a finger".  

Well, there's one thing you (USO) said you would do for once.  Instead of creating programs addressing the  local needs of our military, their family, and veterans or retirees, you spent obscene amounts of funds (from donors) to hire out others (3rd party contractors) to do your <<USO SALARIED>> job.  Even then, you still have nothing to show - programmatically, through service, and definitely not through fundraising.  

And where was any oversight from USO World?  Crickets.  There's actually regional staff?!  YGBSM.  It can only get better higher up if it's this great down here.  

Between the cronyism, lying, stealing, grandstanding, and overall laziness of the senior and Board leadership (which trickles down, unfortunately), it's no wonder this is an organization that truly missed the boat.

It is heartbreaking - especially with what this organization used to mean to the military, and what a joke it is now.

review_title: I LOVE working at the USO. It is rewarding, fulfilling, and challenging all at once!
pros: The USO operates on 8 core values that govern all we do -- mission first, innovation, gratitude, do the right thing, collaboration, respect, excellence and accountability. These provide an umbrella for executing one of the best missions in the world -- lifting the spirits of America's troops and their families! We work in a dynamic environment to serve those who protect our freedoms, and the payback is so rewarding when a service member of their family smiles at something you have done to help make their day. We are such a diverse organization that there are multiple opportunities for personal growth -- all while taking care of our nation's finest.
cons: We have 165 plus centers and mobile programming systems that operate throughout the world, so sometimes communications and corporate initiatives that cross many geographic and time zones can be a challenge! We come together, though, through internal communication systems that we use on a regular basis. It is also important to be mindful of the work-life balance when working for USO -- we are all so passionate about our jobs that it is important to remember to take a little time for oneself...

pros: Teamwork driven, accessible leadership, clear goals and objectives, the mission is wonderful.
cons: working all the time, varied working hours, over tasked

pros: Solid team. Rewarding job. Ability to think outside the box and act on ideas.
cons: No room to move up if you are prior service Army. Tight, low budgets meant to help on a large scale. Can be frustrating.

pros: The best part is meeting members of the military
cons: There is no downside other than travel time

review_title: Great Mission, lack of direction in daily tasks
pros: Serving military and their families is very fullfilling.
cons: Lack of direction in accomplishing tasks and mission

job_title: Center Operations Supervisor in Fairbanks, AK
pros: great company to work for would do so again gladly
cons: no bad review to be found I loved it

job_title: Program and Volunteer Coordinator in Catania
pros: Friendly people, career opportunities, great pay
cons: Schedule varies, late nights and early mornings

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Wappingers Falls, NY
pros: Work life balance, invested in employees
cons: No cons, enjoyed my time there.

pros: This job really gives you the chance to serve those who serve our country. I've been with the organization for under 7 months and I must say- this has been the most fulfilling and exciting job that I have ever done. The benefits are great, the job is fun and just being there for our troops is very rewarding. Whether it's serving food to playing monopoly with a group of service members; this is the best job anyone can ask for!
cons: One that comes to mind would continuously changing our programs with a limited amount of money to work with. It's challenging and it could be stressful but at the end of the day, as long as our troops are happy and we achieve our goal, the stress is completely worth it. Another thing that can be seen as a con is working during the holidays. My family and I celebrate the holidays together. Even if we were separated by countries or states, we would always find a way to be together on the holidays. Since I've been working with the USO, I have worked on many holidays but it was for a good reason. Thanksgiving for example is a holiday that I was grateful to be working. Serving thanksgiving dinners to unaccompanied service members was an amazing experience and I was happy to be spending my holiday with them.

pros:
Great mission but doesn't every nonprofit cite that?
USO hires plenty of talented people
Field staff and volunteers are the amazing spirit behind the organization
Free parking/metro
Gym at the HQ
cons:
Dramatic and biased layoffs occur every other year
Incredibly top heavy organizational structure (mostly unwarranted given the lack of complex work output from the HQ)
The talented people are paralyzed because the culture makes it difficult to do good work
The talented people don't stay long so expect lots of turnover and pitching in to support the revolving door of vacancies; don't expect to be recognized for the latter
Disconnect between HQ and field, and much more so than other other HQ-field affiliate structure; this is detrimental to the future of the organization
Some mid-senior managers are either not skilled in people or project management, or simply working to keep the status quo and their own jobs safe (probably not unique to the USO)
Sweeping changes to realign and reduce salaries-mostly warranted given the nature of nonprofits; unfortunately those changes have been packaged as a career growth "step" program

review_title: Poorly run at the top and HQ is a challenging work environment
pros: Great mission of supporting our service members, good and hardworking staff. Wonderful volunteers in the field.
cons: Poor leadership and work environment at HQ in Arlington. (Note that many of the positive reviews are from the field offices and volunteers outside of HQ.) , Revenue for the organization has been declining, donor base is aging and not being replaced, organization has done a poor job in conveying relevancy and continues to hang its hat on the declining conflicts in the Southwest Asia. A sound strategy for turning the organization around is elusive as they focus fully on short-term wins and how to get dollars in quickly. Not sustainable or smart.  The CEO has made two massive staffing cuts in his brief tenor -- people are expendable as they cut staff to mask revenue declines.  Talent and innovative thinking is less important than keeping your head down.  The environment has become one of fear. Staff report that senior leadership does not "live the values".  All very sad given the underlying mission of the organization and its rich heritage.

review_title: With 40,000 military nonprofits, you can do better
pros: 30 days of vacation (though you can't take advantage of it because there's always too much work to do so you never feel comfortable taking it). Convenient to metro. Opportunity to serve and meet some great people who serve our country.  Compensation is generally a little better than comparable nonprofits.
cons: Cold-hearted leadership team at HQs don't care about the employees, except for Operations where there's a great leader at the helm (former military). If you're going to work here, work in the field at a center - people are much happier there as they are closer to the mission delivery and far away from HQs. Several employees have left to go to Operation Homefront, a kinder, gentler, more down-to-earth military nonprofit. People are working on top of each other since they are busting out of the space and management won't address the space problems. The organization touts 8 core values but leadership ignores them.

pros:
Amazing people with a sincere passion to support the military and their families.  Great benefits including an amazing 401k program (the best I've ever seen in 20 years of employment) and 30 days of Paid time off for all full-time employees!

I love that my work has purpose and get the warm fuzzy feelings everyday.   After working in Corporate America for 20 years, it's amazing to have a purpose to give back and make the world a better place.  (sounds cheesy, right?)  I mean it!  I love it here!!
cons: Being a non-profit organization, it can be hard to compete with salaries of some corporations.  That being said, there is a huge value to feeling good about your work and helping others on a daily basis.  If you have  a heart to give back, this is a great place.

review_title: A demanding workplace with a fantastic mission, an evolving corporate culture and big goals for the future.
pros:
*Opportunity to take on lots of responsibility and growth based on performance. You won't be bored. 

*Friendly environment of mostly kind and supportive colleagues. 

*A measured, step-based promotion plan to ensure those who meet/exceed objectives grow in title, pay and scope. 

*A truly unique and meaningful charitable mission. 

*Excellent benefits and competitive compensation.
cons:
*Layers of internal processes have produced a bureaucratic culture that slows down innovation growth. 

*Pressure to meet targets is quickly increasing (not necessarily a bad thing) without adaquate resources to deliver (maybe just a nonprofit thing). 

*Many workplace policies look great on paper (training & work culture development especially) but fail to deliver on the bottom line. There is a set of core values new hires are compelled to adopt that are rarely revisited anytime after orientation. 

*Rapidly increasing formal environment. Pressure to dress in business formal/business casual attire nearly every day.

review_title: Its a great organization to work for,  that has an incredible mission.
pros: Its a great organization to work with that has an incredible mission. Its a job that I want to go to everyday and I appreciate and respect my co-workers and peers. The scope of programs that we are able to bring out to the military communities are the best part of the job, and it makes you want to do even more. Benefits are competitive, and while be slightly less than a for-profit organization there is a healthy compensation package that is offered to staff.
cons: There are some communication challenges within the corporate leadership and upper regional leadership. Budgets are small and unfortunately there are high overhead costs that could be mitigated better.  There has also been an increase of micromanagement within the last year, which has had a negative impact to  morale  and leadership confidence.

review_title: So proud to have the honor of working here!
pros: I have never been so proud to work at a place as I am to be at the USO.  The mission, the values, the ability to contribute to serving our troops all combine to make this a phenomenal place to work.  The organization is rolling out programs to support soldiers in transition, looking at ways to reach and support soldiers every minute of every day.  It's a place where you can get up every day happy to be part of an organization that does such meaningful work.
cons: Many people here are so very dedicated that they never slow down, and eventually the stress will catch up to them.  With all the new energy and change, there are bound to be some unhappy people, but they are in the minority, and there is usually a background story.

review_title: This is a dream job, and a way to give back to the military who do so much for us!
pros: The mission of this company is strongly supported with all of the actions of the employees and volunteers. We are able to get one on one interaction with the people that we are here to support, and this job encourages us to be creative and passionate about how we accomplish the mission. The company is also great about benefits and vacation time, allowing us to refresh and regroup so that we can work to the best of our ability and not get burnt out. Overall, I can not imagine a better or more fulfilling job.
cons: For the particular region that I work in, I am far from home, and that is not always ideal for everyone. This is not a job with set hours, although they do try to keep it consistent. Personally, I like that things are not monotonous, but it is not for everyone.

pros: Great mission and cause. Those who understand the cause first-hand add considerable value to the organization, but unfortunately that number is low among Senior Management and Leadership. Good benefits, such as 30 days of PTO per year.
cons: Unfortunately, leadership often appears disengaged or absent entirely, despite claims of having an "open-door" policy, and recurring dishonest and extremely inappropriate practices are a constant drag on morale. Not all employees are valued equally, where personal friendship with the SVP seems the best path to advancement regardless of performance. The optics of these practices lead only to frustration for those who provide verifiable results to the organization. Senior Management often fails to set an example by flagrantly abusing perks associated with title.

pros: This job was creative, eclectic and a new challenge each day.  There were only 3 employees with the rest volunteers.  We worked together tightly and wore many hats. It was fun and challenging.
cons:
Management.  It was a charter system with many layers. Each USO had a charter which fell under the main headquarters in DC. When they got into a heated dispute, the charter was "pulled" and all employees that local management hired were let go.

Very bad form.

review_title: Great Mission, Horrible, Horrible Work Environment
pros:
The MIssion which are the Troops
The Paycheck
cons: In Southwest Asia, people are hired rarely based on ability, but on who is well liked. The Regional Management  are very much into favoritism and managing by threats of "If You don't like it here, leave."  Try as they may, HR in Arlington, VA has no clue what really happens in Afghanistan and Kuwait, so they rely on the Regional and Center Managers..who are often unqualified for the positions they hold. For such a great organization, it is truly sad how unprofessional the Management is.

pros: Enjoyed the nuts & bolts of serving troops & family members, staff is surely dedicated to see to the troops needs and desires especially those deployed.
cons: Fat paychecks for a non-profit charity to VP and above while nickel-and-dimeing the field centers. Cross sharing of best practices lacking.  Little to no training on specific company procedures for day-to-day management.

pros: The job was a lot of fun and a very rewarding way to give back.
cons: The biggest down side to the job was the hours, the organization uses the term "Exempt Employee" as an acceptable substitute for slave. I had to work constantly, sometimes even on PTO.  Management is to short sighted and very domineering and unorganized toward employees.

review_title: Fun, stressful, faced paced and rewarding!
pros: Supporting our service members and their families, for me this is the most important aspect of my job. Ensuring that our facility and staff have the skills and equipment necessary to provide top notch programming to thousands of men and women each and every year.
cons: Fast paced environment, challenging to work for a non-profit organization especially one that operates overseas.

review_title: Ok place to work if you like a slow pace...
pros: The missions is very rewarding.  Benefits and work-life balance is great.
cons: Employees at all levels are not held accountable, but especially at the director and higher levels.  Improvement/change is slow.  Meetings are a waste of time.  In the meantime, you spend all your time like a hamster in wheel doing the same thing inefficiently over and over again.

review_title: Best company to work for: Hands Down
job_title: Duty Manager in Jalālābād, Nangarhar Province
pros: The mission, the freedom to do whatever you wanted if it could benefit the program and improve the lives of the troops. Great pay and vacation benefits. EXELLENT 403b plan. Travel.
cons: Austere conditions. Sometimes "Clicky" coworkers and management. Getting in and out of theater was a real grind since we had to fly space A on Air Force transport planes.

review_title: a well meaning organization with no internal organization or structure
pros: Working for a great cause, amazing coworkers, flexible work schedule, great opportunities for advancement
cons: Total lack of respect for employees by Executive Director and board. Discrimination for females and nonmilitary employees

pros:
-Supporting US military in a deployed setting
-Fulfilling work
-Autonomy
-Free housing, free food, Special Pays, Tax Exempt Status, easy to save money
-Travel days, travel allowance
-Personal growth
cons:
-Extreme living, poor work/life balance
-High turnover, not sustainable work
-Danger, stress, loneliness, time zone separation from USA

pros: Almost every single coworker WANTS to be here, and BELIEVES in the mission.  This makes all the difference.  When you work with people who care about the same things you do (like being there for our troops and their families), it doesn't matter what department you're in, you're going to work hard collaborating on this common goal.  When entertainment goes to send out the tours to the middle east, literally 40 or so people from all different departments offer to help carry boxes through the building to load up the trucks.  Then entertainment makes homemade cookies to thank everybody.  It's that kind of a workplace.  It's fun working with people from literally all over the world.  It's always something new, and that makes the humdrum things more interesting because it's always mixed with the exciting.  Then ultimately the best reward is to read the stories and emails of the troops the USO has touched.  To know you've had a small part in making that happen is the best feeling!  Also, 30 days of PTO a year is a pretty sweet reward too (who needs sick days anyway, I use all of them for vacation)!
cons: Innovation can be difficult when there are multiple layers of higher ups to get through to get an idea approved.  While I say that almost every single coworker believes in the mission and wants to be here, when you do encounter those rare few who don't want to work hard it's incredibly frustrating because then you have to overcompensate.

review_title: After leaving the military the USO was the only employer I've found which has been able to give me a sense of purpose.
pros: Great culture!! Purpose-driven colleagues. Great location in the middle of Arlington, and a brand everyone respects. With many jobs you might be in a rush to get home from work so you can take off the branded polo shirt before you go to happy hour but not at the USO. It's almost like a badge of honor in the D.C. area. More than a few times service members have offered to buy me a drink or have said "thank you" because of those three letters on my shirt or cap. When you leave work every day, you feel like you helped change someones life for the better. The health benefits are great. So good, in fact, that even my wife who works for a healthcare company doesn't have better coverage. lol. True story. She makes like three times my salary and she's on my PPO. haha.
cons: Arlington is expensive, and being a 501c3 non-profit the USO isn't breaking the bank with super high salaries and they shouldn't be expected to. That would only decrease their GuideStar ratings. They also have not been very keen on the idea of working remote, so you might have to live out of town and commute in, which is doable here with Metro. Fortunately if you do have to take metro the USO gives you a monthly metro stipend as one of the benefits, so your commute should be free. In my experience the only other "con" I've seen has been the limitation of personal and professional growth.

review_title: Great Organization to work for , S.W.A region Employee
pros:
- Gratifying work in the field supporting the men and women in uniform. 
- Competitive benefits i.e paid vacation, 401(k), etc 
- Tight knit relationship between peers and leadership, Almost like family due to small number of total employees and working in remote areas. 
- Great support structure system from the regional leadership and headquarters for those that work in remote locations such as Afghanistan, Kuwait etc. 
- Every day, quarter, year is an adventure full of various ways of supporting troops directly, Daily programs, Holiday programs etc
cons: - Possibility of working and living in hazardous regions of the world alongside military service members.

pros: Everyone here really cares about their job and truly believes in the USO mission.  I don’t have that feeling where I’ve not wanted to go into work, in fact I really love going to my job every day and it helps that everyone is really positive and makes it a fun environment.  All employees are willing to help in any instance which is extremely helpful.  Overall, I think the USO has an incredible mission and would highly recommend everyone to work here!
cons: The workload can be a little stressful at first, but what we do here makes the end result worth it!

review_title: The President & CEO is a Lousy Leader & Manipulator
pros: The USO has a great mission and some very dedicated people at Corporate and out in the Regions. For the most part, their mission of lifting the spirits of troops and their families is met.
cons:
The two HUGE flaws at the USO is the President & CEO and the Senior Management Team. The President is probably the worst leader I've ever met and he will manipulate a situation to serve his own needs at the drop of a hat. 

The Senior Management Team is dysfunctional at best, each having their own agenda, with the inability to solve issues and work together as a team. The President feeds this dysfunction by his lack of leadership and inability to set realistic priorities based on the true needs of our troops and their families. 

Case in point are his number one priority; the building of the two Warrior & Family Centers, one at Ft. Belvoir and the other at Walter Reed in Bethesda. The building of these two new centers is to serve only one real purpose; to feed his giant ego. He wants to build these two new centers for the sole purpose of having a personal legacy.

These two new centers will NEVER operate at full capacity because, thank god, there are not now and most likely, will never be enough wounded troops and family members to fully utilize them. The President has spent the last 4 years selling his dream for a need that barely exists. He has done nothing but spin half truths and lies in order to shove these two new centers down the throats of the military leadership and worst, the donors of the USO. 

The worst part about this whole story is, he is taking funds away from the active duty troops and their families to support a wounded population of less than 9,000 troops, and that was at the height of the wars. Instead of doing some real, meaningful fact finding, some focus groups with active duty troops and their families to find out what they really need, he chooses to build these two new Warrior & Family Centers to fulfill a need that is being met by organizations that can meet the needs of wounded troops far better than the USO ever thought possible.

pros: The Mission!!  (if you want to work for this organization, stay away from Arlington HQ.  Work in a center...thats where you see the mission at work), close to metro, good PTO (but will you actually have time to use it?)...90% of the staff members at the HQ are wonderful people.  They make doing the work fun.
cons: Senior Leadership! They are so self centered that they don't care about the employees that actually do the work, they just want to make sure the organization looks good from the outside.   Check out the current 990.  Finances are a mess and it makes doing your job (because no one knows which budget to work with) very difficult. There is no job security. (in the last few months at least 30 people have left- either by their own choice or a decision by Senior Leadership to "reorganize") HR will just lie to you during the interview process, don't be fooled like I was.  There is no room for growth (the STEPs process is a joke).  The only way you will advance is if you are  are close with an SVP- they will create a new position for you and ignore those who have been working for the organization for years.

pros:
-Superb field staff
-Excellent benefits and PTO
cons: The culture is poisonous and dramatic. Senior leadership is unstable and delusional, frequently putting others down to build themselves up. If you are not adored by leadership, watch out. You will likely be disciplined for minor, often irrational reasons. Many employees who work diligently are neglected and disrespected. There is constant drama in the office (feuds, affairs, lies).

pros: I never envisioned working for the USO, though I long respected their mission and services, but I fell in love after I began volunteering!  When the opportunity arose, I wanted nothing else than to work for the USO. I've been at this for over two years and this is the most rewarding work I could ever imagine doing. Every day is something special; with different opportunities to reach those who need support and encouragement. Its often hard work, both emotionally and physically, but I hope to never leave the field. Most of my upper levels of management are very supportive and encouraging. When working with HQ, I can expect to get quick and relevant feedback and help. After two years, I can still say that this is the best job in the world. Also, we have great benefits- tuition reimbursement (and they even cover books), excellent and inexpensive health insurance, and a great retirement plan. When our health insurance premiums were going to go up in 2015, the board decided to instead eat those costs as a way of thanking the employees for their hard word. In my previous field, that NEVER would have happened. I feel valued, appreciated, and respected with the USO.
cons: When an employee's heart isn't in it, it hurts everyone. There are people who have lost sight of the mission and view this as just another job. Unfortunately, that creates a greater burden for everyone else. In SWA, I believe there are maturity issues among some staff members, and there often seems to be an imbalance of responsibilities. It often seems the same few people are tasked with assignments and duties, while others do next to nothing (or plan poorly for what they are given and the team is left scrambling), and seem to have no repercussions. That part of it gets rather frustrating, but I realize I am not all-knowing; the staff member may have extenuating circumstances.

pros: The mission to support troops and their families is beyond rewarding. Those at centers (a.k.a. in the field) experience this first-hand on a daily basis and it's a motivation to keep doing good things. Fellow employees in the field (around the world) and some at the headquarters are great people to know and to work with. Some volunteers are true gems and it's amazing to see how many selfless servants donate their time day after day, year after year, through good times and crises.
cons:
- Toxic management and no truly anonymous/protective system to report issues/problems. 
- Too many middle managers
- Field is understaffed
- A culture of favoritism 
- Disconnect between headquarters and the field
- Disconnect between Core Values and actually practicing them
- Extremely poor internal communications
- Ever increasing demands and decreasing resources to meet such demands
- Ever increasing micromanagement
- Extremely difficult and occasionally impossible to "do the right thing" for troops/families, even volunteers
- Not enough compensation for field staff
- Difficult to find work-life balance and meet job demands
- Little training

review_title: So much potential, so little leadership
pros: Wonderful mission. Great need for their services.
cons: While under the leadership of Sloan Gibson the organization flourished and grew. The focus was on the mission and there was a huge desire to ensure staff had a path for advancement and a decent quality of life.  Following his departure quality quickly plummeted and staff was rarely a consideration.

review_title: No support, no direction, give an inch they take a mile
pros: The USO Mission is the only thing that hold a lot of staff here.  What the USO does for our troops is tremendous
cons:
- Work Life Balance HORRIBLE
- No support from director and above
- No training but penalized for not following standards
- Benefits and Compensation is going downhill for everything they are requiring from their staff
- One of the core values is DO THE RIGHT THING and USO lacks that tremendously especially in the PACIFIC.  It is more like turn a blind eye.  Huge turn over in the PACIFIC for lack of leadership and support

review_title: My experience at the USO was rewarding
pros: Great atmosphere, Employee espirit de corps events, company outings, online self development, people with the same passion to serve the troops, metro allowance or free garage parking, holiday events, travel (if applicable to your position), fair performance review process, great vacation policy- 30 days a year.
cons: Minimal advancement opportunities. Turnover in certain departments. Really I do not have too many cons based on my personal experiences. Everyone's experience is not the same.

pros: Volunteers and community make it all worthwhile.
cons: Management is terrible. Lots of wasted time and money. There is a severe disconnect between regional, headquarters and the centers. HR is truly the worst I've ever seen. More hiring power should go to the centers, as Arlington HQ has zero clue on what each center needs.

pros:
- The generous PTO plan
- some of the staff really care about the mission and are great to work with
-  USO volunteers and center staff are awesome
cons:
- leadership does not have your back and shows little appreciation for staff
- things have been in flux under the CEO for the 2+ years he's been there.. there's an unclear direction and a lot of feeling of uncertainty 
- it's a top heavy organization with little room to grow
- workload can be overwhelming & leadership does not give you proper direction to determine what should be given priority

review_title: That Juneteenth post was cute, but it doesn't erase the toxic, non-inclusive and favoritism-tainted work environment
pros: Unlimited PTO (not uncommon anymore, but still nice). Solid salary to be non-profit (but you could get laid off around Thanksgiving or Christmas, so maybe save that money?). Benefits are excellent.
cons:
If you are looking for a toxic workplace with inept leadership and some diversity but a complete lack of inclusion, then the USO is for you.  Don’t let the Juneteenth social media post fool you, there is such an abundance of dysfunction, leadership failure, conscious, and unconscious bias happening there that it would make your head spin.  While companies and organizations across the country claim to be “listening now” to voices willfully unheard in the workplace, my hope is that the lazy and biased HR department and senior management will take an honest look at how they are conducting business if they wish to remain viable in this new environment.

With the exception of one member of the C-suite, the entire senior leadership team is too wealthy and elitist to have actually joined the military themselves, yet they enjoy attempting to run the organization as if it is an unofficial branch.  The culture is fear-based with a title-driven hierarchy where there is a different standard of treatment for Director-level and above staff versus Senior Manager and below.  Expect to be talked down upon and have your opinions deeply discounted, if acknowledged at all; there is an environment where junior staff do not feel valued.  There is a profound lack of collegiality in email exchanges among staff.  Many of the assertions in previous reviews regarding favoritism are absolutely true.  There were clear discrepancies in how individuals were treated, based on proximity of their relationship to senior management staff.  There is one particular case where an employee with exceptional proximity to senior management staff was promoted to a position without meeting the time-in-seat nor experience qualifications for the role.  This had a lingering demoralizing effect on the department in question at the time.

An appalling lack of integrity within the Development department was revealed when another now-former assistant of senior management staff distributed invitations to a secret intra-department mentorship program that were interspersed with meeting agendas.  As a result, several individuals who were not selected for the secret program were made aware of its existence.  Senior management staff tried to cover their tracks during that meeting, but the damage was already done.  No one had any idea that this program existed, how long it was going on, what the qualifications were, nor what the selection process was.  It was unclear how participation or lack thereof affected promotions and/or assignments.  Unsurprisingly, there were no black or brown employees intended for or selected to the program.  The Juneteenth social media post is quite the departure for the USO.  Rarely have they ever acknowledged the accomplishments nor achievements of people of color who have served our military proudly; not through Black History Month or any other ethnic history month social posts, cultivation of relationships with current service members or veterans of color, nor consideration of an inclusive entertainment tour that features more than country music.  The military has historically been one of the most diverse employers in the country, yet the USO willfully misses the mark on acknowledging and championing that.  We’ll see if this post leads to meaningful change, or if it’s just another organization doing performative allyship with no intention to improve anything.

Not only are veterans and employees of color looked over, the voices of millennial and Gen Z staff were regularly ignored, despite the USO having an aging donor base and an alleged active strategy to attract younger donors.  A former senior management staffer attended a workshop on millennials in California but did not want to do a report-out of the meeting, so he had the department spend money to fly the instructor cross-country, put her up in a hotel and teach the exact same course.  Not only did the USO have a team full of millennials who could’ve shared the same information for free, exactly nothing from the course was implemented.  This same senior management staffer also decided to take a development opportunity from me by attending SXSW 2018 in my stead (after I put together a full agenda of military-focused workshops to attend), only to once again have nothing to report out when he returned.  He shared that most of the presenters were people whom he had already met (which he would’ve known from the agenda I prepared, as their names were present), and that he doesn’t like crowds (which a cursory Google search would’ve also made clear would occur at SXSW), so he ended up simply robbing me of a professional development opportunity.  And did I mention this same individual would put dummy meetings on his calendar so he could schedule trips to NYC to get his hair cut and expense his trips back to the USO?  Sadly, this individual was allowed to repeatedly waste donor dollars for years before being shown the door.

The career pathing at the USO also leaves much to be desired.  There was a surprise career development meeting by another senior management staffer and my manager for me, and I was put on the spot about my intended next steps at the USO, without having the opportunity to prepare.  I shared this during my exit interview with HR and learned that no other employee was asked to do this.  During this meeting, the senior management staffer and my manager both belittled and downplayed my aspirations. They were also either ignorant of or dismissive towards my previous work experience, as no one with a genuine interest in understanding a high-performing employee’s next steps would choose to demoralize them instead, right?  I ended up putting together a proposal of increased responsibilities, as well as a request for raise and promotion, which was denied.  The senior management staffer told me that he needed “to see more” over the next six months, but that was never defined nor explained, and thusly could not be made actionable.  I was told to not bring my lap blanket to any more internal meetings in our exceptionally cold office because it “bothered” this senior management staffer and “took away from my executive presence”.  Our office was business casual at the time and we had a jeans policy on Fridays, but my manager who was in this meeting wore jeans every day of the week and nothing was made of how that may affect his executive presence.  In retrospect, it appears this senior staff member simply was annoyed by my blanket; he used performative concern about my career development as a vehicle to reprimand me about something completely unrelated to performance and wouldn’t have been sanctioned by HR.  I’m not sure that person has any idea of what the definition of executive presence is, but I know it has nothing to do with a blanket.

I brought this conversation back up the day I resigned from the USO, and my manager backpedaled so quickly about the things that were said in that meeting that I thought he was going to moonwalk out of his office.  He claimed that the meeting caught him off guard as well and that he was equally unprepared for it, but when it came time to stand up for me as I was being disrespected by this person, he ultimately chose to join in instead of defend me.  Every employee’s professional development should be taken seriously, and singling out a person of color on staff to belittle their goals and put them down over a personal preference that has nothing to do with performance should not and will not be tolerated in the marketplace as it was in the past.

pros: Good cause, much appreciated by Army, supportive lower management, 5 weeks of paid leave annually, tax free income if job is overseas, nice, warm, atmosphere.
cons:
Donations don't always go where donators expect them to go. 
Insufficient policies and guidelines, offices are managed as little franchise branches; you might get lucky and get a great director. You might not and work yourself to death for $8 an hour.

pros:
Working with the military.
Making a difference in the lives of the men and women who serve our country, as well as their families.
cons: Long work hours; no operational support from USO Leadership.  Do more with less. If you want help, get the volunteers to do it (they won't). If you want staff, raise the money to hire them. No appreciation for the diligent work performed by staff.

pros: Love the mission, love the people. Every day is different and the culture is very inviting
cons: Lots of changes in senior management. Communication from top-down is not as strong as it could be.

pros: Excellent benfits package to enntice potential employees
cons: Plenty of departments working together in "collabrative teams"  however no follow through and people are not held accountable for stop gaps in process flow.  Ideas die a quick death as there is no follow through.  Grand ideas and plans with little thought given to implementation.

pros:
The opportunity to work with some of the most dedicated individuals to the mission at hand.
The opportunity to serve our military families and provide the support they need to ensure the safety of our country.
cons:
Lack of professional growth opportunities.
Constant change to mission objectives (this is the nature of the changing military however).

review_title: Positive workplace, but slow and not enough work to go around
pros: Great mission and work environment. Awesome work/life balance and supportive culture.
cons: Toxic people aren't addressed properly; some supervisors don't delegate work down, so many employees are bored and underutilized. Tendency to keep information at the top and doesn't trickle down. No enough training.

pros: Everyone is extremely dedicates and passionate about the mission and providing quality services and programs to service members and their families. Great training. Great teams. Great support. Great people. Flexible.
cons: Like every entity, there are processes and systems that can lead to delays in getting approvals and/or delivering service in the time you planned. Patience and advance planning is key.

pros: pros, I felt that working with and for service members, especially young enlisted members and wounded warriors was so important
cons: the infighting is out of control, senior management screaming at each other, senior management bullying younger employees and using them as scapegoats, terribly mishandled finances

pros: You do work that is special and rewarding. Everyday you walk in and you know your helping a bunch of people. The people are very nice and the work environment is confortable.
cons: There were no cons in working for the USO. Basically you work there because you want to make a difference.

review_title: Excellent Organization with a positive mission!!!
pros: The USO leadership really cares about supporting the mission and keeping costs under control. The leadership and fellow employees have a shared passion for helping service members and their families. Family oriented organization.  Benefits are good.
cons: Pay, but this is being a good steward of the donors money so it is understandable.

review_title: Great company that can provide a stable career in terms of military services.
pros: It was great being able to help military members and their families with what they needed when traveling.
cons: Leadership sometimes does not have you back and shows little appreciation for staff.

pros: Great mission and amazing experience.  They give you great opportunities to take on a lot at an entry-level position.  You can learn a lot at this position.
cons: Sometimes it felt like the organization was running itself like a sorority.  Upper management needs to learn professional and how to properly employees based on job performance and not friendships.

review_title: Great organization with a strong mission
pros:
- Strong, impactful mission that resonates with everyone who works here
- Great benefits
- Competitive salary
- Continually moving forward with innovative projects, programs and initiatives
- Leadership is strong
cons:
- Sometimes feels like there are too many managers and not enough people doing  the leg work
- Turnover is an issue in some Depts., but is being corrected

pros: you know you are making a difference! Cool opportunities, colleagues are great, and you get to meet great people! USO is good about compensation/recognition for overtime and hard work.
cons: long hours, stressful, big work load.

review_title: An Organization of Driven Individuals Dedicated to our Troops
pros:
- Great benefits (plenty of PTO)
- Great new CEO making necessary improvements
- very warm environment/friendly coworkers
- innovative organization, striving to change for the better
- opportunities for growth
- a priceless opportunity to support the armed forces
cons:
- lots of stuff going on all the time, can be hard to keep track of everything
- no real negatives

review_title: Great mission, passionate staff, hard working employees.  The field staff are amazing -- do so much with so little.
pros: You are proud of what you do and who you support.
cons: Senior leadership lacks inspiration.  They don't set the standard for the organization to follow, and they have adversely impacted the culture.

review_title: Great Company, not so great management
pros:
Part of an amazing mission
directly impact lives of soldiers and their families
some freedom and flexibility
cons:
current manager seems focused on things that make them look better
little to no room for innovation
extremely limited IT budget

pros: you get to help the people that really need it
cons:
turn over with upper management,,,  very high,, so things change every day.
if you don't have to deal with them,, you will do just fine

pros: Staff are vey mission focused and committed to supporting service members- very rewarding to work here.
cons: Culture reflects audience with turn-over- change of duty station every three years but wouldn't necessarily call this a negative attribute, more an opportunity for fresh ideas.

review_title: Headquarters in Arlington is a truly hateful place to work.
pros: There really are no pros. No amount of money, time off or other benefits can compensate for this torture chamber experience.
cons: This is the most unbelievably mean-spirited, heartless and unsatisfying place to work. Nothing ever gets done because people quit in droves or are unceremoniously fired usually around Thanksgiving or Christmas.

pros: I volunteered over 500 hours while I was in Germany. I had a wonderful experience working with the employees. I had a great time seeing the faces on the service men and women with all the different events they had for them.
cons: there wasn't any cons for me. I loved it

review_title: Great place to learn the ropes
pros: Rewarding choice when it comes to providing comforts of home and services to our military heroes. The salary is good to.
cons: The expectations of some younger service members sometime exceed the capabilities and resources that are covered under the USOs scope.

review_title: The USO mission makes it all worth it!
pros:
- the benefits are amazing
- I love our employees in the field locations! They are so driven and their commitment never ceases to amaze me!  
- great growth opportunities
cons: - Not enough employees working at some of these high traffic centers

pros: The mission is very rewarding, and the people and travel opportunities were excellent. Very generous PTO and benefits.
cons: Some senior staff is only in it for themselves and the mission seems lost

pros: Fantastic people to work with and even better young troops transitioning to their new service.  LAX USO is 24/7 for our terrific troops and their families.
cons: None.  Couldn't ask for a better, more fulfilling work environment.

pros: Great opportunity to work with volunteers to create great experiences and events for our US Military.
cons: Some processes needed streamlining and software systems updated. Perhaps this has happened since my employment.

pros: Wonderful mission, excellent clients, great resume builder
cons: Little work-life balance, continuously juggling increasing needs with decreasing resources; disconnect with upper level management; salaries aren't commensurate with work load, for those "in the field".

pros: Great benefits, lots of room for improvement, passionate people
cons: It's like being in the military outside of the military; no open door policy. If you are a manager you cannot just send emails to directors or VPs.

pros: the mission is key at the USO. everyone is mission driven and service members love the USO and what they do for their community.
cons: constantly changing processes are confusing and frustrating and impede progress at the uso.

pros: Good PTO program, sense of fulfillment in carrying out worthwhile mission.
cons: Too much focus on fundraising. Company spends too much money on fundraising. Does not partner with other organizations.

review_title: Great Job and company to work for
job_title: Program Coordinator in El Paso, TX
pros: The employees really live by the USO values. Great pay, benefits and managers
cons: There is no down side to working with the USO.

pros: Core values, mission, budget, and support for innovation are key to providing supportive environment for growth.  Attracts top level volunteers to serve the mission.
cons: None to provide at this time.

pros: The mission. The United States military should be treated like gold and some people know this and work hard to ensure that's the case.
cons: Leadership is like President Trump. Delusional, mean, petty and horny. Oversexualized and heavy partying environment. Shameful. Operation Homefront is taking over and is a normal work environment.

review_title: Terrific nonprofit with strong mission delivery and ethical approach to service.
pros: Great benefits package for employees.  Position promotes a work environment filled with autonomy and self-direction.
cons: Fund development strategic planning should provide for greater collaboration and communications with the field.

pros: Immersed in the military community
cons: No upward movement. Employees need more social services experience to include management.

pros:
-Great benefits
- Work directly with transitioning service members
- Benefit concerts & shows
cons: - Communication between HQ and local sites

review_title: left to figure it out on your own with no support from Corporate
pros: taking care of the troops
cons:
Cost of living is not equated into the compensation and there is no concern by corporate...they will just look for someone else to fill the slot
no training anywhere for any one
no support
no interest by senior executives
no direction, no help, no support
Development raising resources for the region is a joke

pros:
- Working under a great mission all employees are passionate about
- Great company culture 
- Learning opportunities are always available
cons: - I did not think there were any cons to working here!

review_title: My USO experience was a great one
pros: Working at the USO is a great experience helping service members find a place to relax makes volunteering worthwhile.
cons: The USO had a great staff hard to find a problem.

pros: Excellent place to work, very family friendly, employees enjoy coming to work and being a part of this company and their mission, excellent benefits
cons: Salary compensation could be more

pros: Some of the best reasons to work here are the people, benefits and the cause. They pay competitively and have a very good environment.
cons: I have not found any cons yet!

review_title: A Non Profit That Cares and Innovates
pros: A mission driven work force that has appetite to innovate and improve.
cons: Pockets of legacy culture that resists taking risks.

pros: Rewarding work. Easy job.  Plus if you are a Veteran because you speak the same language.
cons: Wont get rich. Constant changes to pathfinder in rules, management and leadership. Guidelines are forever changing.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Hickam AFB, HI
pros: It is an amazing way to support the men and women who serve our country.  Great benefits!
cons: Work life Balance is really bad. Extremely high turnover in Hawaii locations. Miromanagement from Area office.

pros: Family feeling, great teammates and fulfilling.
cons: Can be long hours and time consuming.

pros: I truly enjoyed the staff and meeting/assisting all the new family's that came to the Vicenza USO.
cons: I did not experience an cons while volunteering with the USO.

pros: Supportive and friendly environment, great mission
cons: Because it’s a NPO,  everyone is encouraged to do as much as possible with as little as possible

pros: Volunteers are the backbone of this organization, and treated well, as they should be.
cons: Skeleton hourly staff was left to hold all programs. Managers were not willing to support. Upper management is full of cliques and gossip. Work/life balance is nonexistent for hourly staff.

pros: Opportunity to serve the military is one of the greatest satisfactions one could have.  Constantly busy with new things and always a challenge
cons: Some long, but enjoyable, hours at times

pros: Taking care of America's Troops and their families daily - it doesn't get any better!
cons: Opportunities for upward mobility are limited.

review_title: Good work life balance, but not much career opportunity
pros: Good benefit, good work life balance.
cons: Not much development opportunity, salary remains stagnant, high turnover rate, politics.

pros: Great missions helping Veterans, transitioning Service Members, and their families moving navigating civilian employment or education. Wonderful team environment and attitudes.
cons: Turn-over rate and sometimes feeling unsupported.

pros: Workload is not heavy. Friendly environment with less pressure.
cons: Hiring, promotion, and evaluation could be not fair but it's a problem of most companies

pros: An extremely rewarding job, helping our forward deployed service members.
cons: Being away from home (family & friends) is tough.

pros: Great pay for living in Southwest Asia, great vacation time, great healtchare
cons: No growth or ability to transfer within company.

pros: Great PTO benefits. Good salaries. Terrific mission of helping troops.
cons: Health care benefits changed often, never above average.

pros: Love working with the USO. It’s an amazing organization!
cons: Pay is not really negotiable as it is a non-profit

pros: Great opportunity to assist transitioning service members and military spouses achieve their goals.
cons: I have no "cons" to offer for the position.

job_title: WELCOME CENTER ATTENDANT in Fort Hood, TX
pros: Great hours. Other volunteers were easy to work with.
cons: Needed to work a lot of shifts. Front desk could get boring.

review_title: I love working with the USO!
pros: Feels great to support our military!
cons: None - at least not yet.

pros: Fast faced; interesting work; travel
cons: political; Changes happen quickly; not always easy to understand

pros: Amazing company to work for enjoyed every minute of it
cons: No cons very organized and friendly

pros: They are flexible to work
cons: Not really ever person is super nice

pros: Best way to give back to your military community.
cons: You may work on a lot of holidays and weekends.

pros: Wonderful people working here. Always made me feel welcome and I loved the work they did
cons: Sometimes slightly disorganized, but otherwise great!

pros: USO has an incredible team and volunteers
cons: Pay doesn't equal the time and amount of work put into being successful.

pros:
Pay is good
The people at work 
The benefits are good for a single person
cons: i have none at this time

pros: Great employee benefits--30 PTO/Sick days right away
cons: SVP's can be disconnected from what is going on within their departments

pros: People work because they believe in the cause
cons: Lack of processes and way to many responsibilities.

review_title: Worst experience of a life time
job_title: Chief Operating Officer in Derby, NY
pros: the only reason is the troops
cons: Central office is awful - too much manipulation with donor funds and more focused on their self importance than really taking care of the troops

job_title: Center Operations and Program Manager in Copperas Cove, TX
pros: Work closely with military service members and their families.
cons: Hours may somewhat personal time.

pros: - Great sense of community and job security
cons: - Advancement potential is not as plentiful

pros: Great benefits and room for growth
cons: really no cons in this type of job

pros: Good benefits (including 30 days PTO). Love the mission
cons: Low pay, high turn over.

pros: Great place to volunteer no cons.
cons: Didn't have one it was a really fulfilling place.

pros: Outstanding organization. Innovative leadership. Commitment to the mission. Growth opportunities.
cons: No cons at this time.

pros: Getting to serve those who serve
cons: No cons to speak of at this time

pros: Great place to work. Highly recommend.
cons: Nothing bad to say about the company.

pros: Benefits package is good compared to other NGOs
cons: Leadership at the Arlington office has taken on too much and this causes them to make poor strategy and process decisions.

pros: The benefits are outstanding depending on where you work.
cons: The pay could be better.

pros: Great PTO policy for staff
cons: Some solos and internal comms could be improved.

pros:
great benefits
great company values
fulfilling job
cons: none that i can think of

pros: Great benefits and relaxed atmosphere
cons: Limited growth potential and politics are seen

pros: Mission, Who the USO serves
cons: Poor Leadership, No Support from Leadership

pros: Great enviornment, everyone is friendly
cons: small office. but great people

pros: The organizational mission is amazing!
cons: The operational elements of the organization are shocking!

pros: Good mission, the local centers on base are filled with passionate people with great intentions.
cons: Corporate office is clueless. Filled with Internal conflicts, gossip, cover yourself mentality, lack of departmental integration and poor leadership/management

pros: Great organization with the best mission.
cons: Little work/ life balance

pros: Co workers are really fun
cons: Managers could always do better

pros: Awesome work place, great mission!
cons: None none none none none

pros: Flexible hours, generous paid time off
cons: Fraud/abuse/waste of company resources. Management does not take seriously when things reported. Worst company ever to work for, feels like a dumb for working hard here
